metadata.court: High Court Of Delhi At New Delhi

text:
[Cites 
5
, Cited by 
0
]

Delhi High Court - Orders

Shubham Garg vs State Gnct Of Delhi And Anr on 16 July, 2024

Author: 
Neena Bansal Krishna

Bench: 
Neena Bansal Krishna

 $~12
 * IN THE HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
 + BAIL APPLN. 618/2024
 SHUBHAM GARG .....Petitioner
 Through: Mr. Diwanshu Sahgal, Advocate.

 versus

 STATE GNCT OF DELHI AND ANR .....Respondents
 Through: APP for the State with ASI Jitender
 Kumar, PS Bhajanpura, New Delhi.
 Mr. Amit Kumar and Mr. Prakhyat
 Sharma, Advocates for Complainant.

 CORAM:
 HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE NEENA BANSAL KRISHNA
 ORDER

 % 16.07.2024

 1. The Anticipatory Bail Application under 
Section 438
 CrPC, has been
 filed on behalf of the petitioner, for grant of anticipatory bail for the offence
 under FIR No. 139/2024 under 
Sections 498A
/
406
/
34
 of the IPC and 3/4 of
 
Dowry Prohibition Act
, registered at Police Station Bhajanpura, District
 Central, Delhi.

 2. It is submitted in the application that the petitioner is the husband of
 the respondent No. 2. The petitioner got married to the respondent No.2 on
 09.12.2021. The present FIR got registered on 02.02.2024 against the
 petitioner and four other family members i.e. the father-in-law, mother-in-
 law, sister-in-law and brother-in-law. All other applicants have been granted
 bail on 09.02.2024, by the learned ASJ, while the Bail Application of the

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 17/07/2024 at 21:46:02
 petitioner, Mr. Shubham Garg, has been rejected.

 3. The respondent No.2/wife has made voluminous complaints to the
 police and has manipulated and fabricated a big story about incidence but
 has not cited any incidences in which she was bodily shamed, tortured
 mentally or physically.

 4. It is submitted that the petitioner is willing to join the investigation, as
 and when called by the IO. Furthermore, he undertakes not to tamper any
 evidence and abide by any other terms that may be imposed by the Court.
 Hence, the anticipatory bail under 
Section 438
 CrPC is sought.

 5. The interim protection was granted to the petitioner by this Court vide
 Order dated 23.02.2024. He has joined the investigation on 24.02.2024 and
 16.03.2024, when he was called by the IO. The IO, who is present in the
 Court, submits that he has not called the petitioner thereafter. No custodial
 interrogation of the accused is required.

 6. The objections have been filed on behalf of the complainant/wife,
 who has given the details of the incident of 21.02.2022, on which date
 allegedly the petitioner had slapped and assaulted her. Similar incidents have
 also been narrated. The petitioner's attitude is claimed to be inconsiderate
 and in contempt of the directions of this Court. The bail application is,
 therefore, seriously opposed on behalf of the complainant.

 7. Submissions heard.

 8. This is a case where the FIR No. 139/2024 under 
Sections
 498A
/
406
/
34
 of the IPC and 3/4 of 
Dowry Prohibition Act
, Police Station
 Bhajanpura, District Central, Delhi, has been registered on the allegations
 made by the complainant of being subjected to cruelty and assault, after her
 marriage. The accused is the husband, who has joined the investigation as

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 17/07/2024 at 21:46:02
 and when called by the IO. No custodial interrogation is sought by the IO.
 Considering the totality of the circumstances, it is directed that in the event
 of his arrest, the applicant/petitioner shall be released forthwith, with the
 following conditions:-

 a) The applicant/petitioner shall furnish a personal bond in the
 sum of Rs.25,000/- with one surety of the like amount, to the
 satisfaction of the Investigating Officer/Arresting Officer.

 b) The applicant/petitioner shall not contact, nor visit, nor offer
 any inducement, threat or promise to any of the prosecution witnesses
 or other persons acquainted with the facts of case. The petitioner shall
 not tamper with evidence nor otherwise indulge in any act or omission
 that is unlawful or that would prejudice the proceedings in the
 pending trial.

 c) The applicant/petitioner shall join the investigations as and
 when directed by the IO.

 d) The applicant/petitioner shall produce all the requisite
 information, documents in his power and possession, as and when
 directed by the Investigating Officer.

 9. The Petition is disposed of accordingly.

 NEENA BANSAL KRISHNA, J
 JULY 16, 2024/RS

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 17/07/2024 at 21:46:02

 and when called by the IO. No custodial interrogation is sought by the IO.

suggested_precedents.full_citation: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 8 SCC 273
suggested_precedents.legal_principle: Mandatory arrest not required for offences punishable less than 7 years
